{{very long|date=October 2018}} {{coord|42|59|08.66|N|83|30|34.05|W|type:city_scale:10000|display=title}}'''Louhelen Bahá'í School''' is one of three leading institutions owned by the [[National Spiritual Assembly]] of the [[Bahá'í Faith|Bahá'ís]] of the United States. The others are [[Green Acre Bahá'í School]] and [[Bosch Bahá'í School]]. Louhelen is near [[Davison, Michigan]].
The school property was bought for Bahá'í purposes in 1930 by the new married couple Lou and Helen Eggleston and they hosted a picnic that year. The first "school" session was held in 1931 and was run via a committee organized by the national community through the 1930s and 40s. Innovations in the period were adding distinct sessions for youth and junior youth and practicum "laboratory" sessions. All the while the material setting was also advanced. In 1947 the Egglestons donated the school property valued over $50k and the National Spiritual Assembly of the US bought the residence which was organically part of the school. The work of maintaining the site was then kept by two committees and on-site managers though the Egglestons continued to associate with the school into the early 1950s. Lou died in 1953 while their daughter assisted the school in 1955. For a period of two years, however, the school was shut down as were all the [[Bahá'í schools]], in 1949 and 1950 to conserve resources for the cost of finishing the [[Bahá'í House of Worship (Wilmette, Illinois)|Bahá'í House of Worship in Wilmette]] and to clearly establish the thrust of work of [[Pioneering (Bahá'í)|promulgating the religion]] in Latin America.
Activities resumed and continued through the 1960s into the early 1970s. However a safety situation developed and in 1974 the school was closed by the national assembly. An investment of $1.8 million followed with plans drawn up and construction projects carried out from 1980 to 1982 and the school re-opened with some buildings restored, others replaced and the mission more explicitly being a residential college and conference center.
A number of subject areas have been advanced across the periods of the school. One was race unity, a subject at the school explicitly since 1932 when Maye Gift's talks on race led to a compilation that was well received in multiple reprints. The school welcomed inter-racial couples, members of diverse races, and a project supporting black students going to attend integrating schools in Greenville, SC, in 1964 was undertaken and a socioeconomic development program Understanding Racism initiative in 1986. Books were also developed from other presentations at the school - some of [[Stanwood Cobb]]'s work was gathered from working for a school session, and the text of ''The Divine Art of Living'' evolved from presentations. Moslem and Christian subjects were studied early on. Later a residential college program supported students who stayed at the school and were students in area colleges. Scholars of the religion gathered annually at the school in the form of the [[Association for Bahá'í Studies]] and the Irfan Colloquia and attracted performers like [[Andy Grammar]], and [[Kevin Locke (musician)|Kevin Locke]]. The school also supported a grandparents-and-grandkids program of learning indigenous Indian cultural history. Jr youth projects have been posted to [[YouTube]].
== Early history ==
=== Pre-history ===
The [[Genesee County, Michigan|Genesee County]] area was developed by Euro-Americans following the development of an [[Indiana Territory]] and its dissolution. Then, the region went through transitions from a [[Michigan Territory|territory]] to a state. Freeman Sweers established the farm near [[Davison, Michigan]] in the latter 1800s and sold to a D. P. Hall.<ref name="Impact">{{cite book |title=Reconstruction of M-15 from I-75 to I-69, Oakland and Genesee Counties: Environmental Impact Statement |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=aJ01AQAAMAAJ&pg=RA3-PA4 |year=2010 |pages=3–5}}</ref> In 1924, Sweers bought into a development in Florida.<ref>{{cite news |title=Coral Gables sales for day over $100,000 |newspaper=The Miami News |location=Miami, FL |page=22 |date=4 Feb 1924 |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/15539425/freeman_sweers_of_davison_mi_buys_into/ | access-date =Jan 25, 2018}}</ref> About the time of the [[Great Depression in the United States]] and in bad condition, the farm was bought by Lou (Lewis W.) and Helen Eggleston.<ref name="Impact" /> Lou was born about 1873, worked in heating industry, and then, at about the age of 50, Lou married Helen and bought the farm, then about 268 acres.<ref name="LouBio">{{cite news |title='Natural' food, by Curt Haseltine |newspaper=Detroit Free Press |location=Detroit, MI |page=18 |date=16 Mar 1952 |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/15380368/profile_of_bahai_lewis_w/ | access-date =Jan 25, 2018}}</ref> Helen was daughter of E. D. and Mrs. Whitney, of Lansing.<ref>{{cite magazine |title=Baha'i summer meet opens today |newspaper=Lansing State Journal |location=Lansing, MI |page=9 |date=27 Jun 1937 |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/15378103/louhelen_bahai_school_central_states/ | access-date =Jan 25, 2018}}</ref>
==== 1930 ====
Helen, still going by her maiden name of Whitney, sent a message to the ''[[Bahá'í News]]'', early monthly periodical of the religion, published in October 1930, of the intention of setting it up as a dairy farm "to operate as far as possible along Baha'i lines".<ref>{{cite magazine |title=Baha'i farm in Michigan |magazine=Bahá'í News |issn=0195-9212 |page=6 |issue=45 |date=Oct 1930 |url=http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=01&page=352 | access-date = Jan 25, 2018}}</ref><ref name="LouhelenHistory">{{cite web |url=http://www.louhelen.org/history |title=Louhelen history |date=2017 |publisher=National Spiritual Assembly of the Bahá'ís of the United States | access-date =Feb 3, 2018}}</ref> In the face of the extending troubles of the Depression that year, a "picnic" was held; it was one of two informal picnics Bahá'ís held in Michigan that year.<ref>{{cite magazine |title=Reports from teaching committee; 4. Informal Baha'i gatherings held during the Spring and Summer |author1=Reginald Collison |author2=Doris McKay |author3=Louis G. Gregory |author4=Albert D. Heist |author5=May Maxwell |magazine=Bahá'í News |location= |page=5 |issue=46 |date=Nov 1930 |url=http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=01&page=359 | access-date =Jan 25, 2018}}</ref>
The name "Louhelen", a contraction of their first names, was originally used as in "Louhelen Ranch".<ref name="LouBio" /> Louhelen was also the name of their daughter and they also had a son Lewis Jr. both of which came along later.<ref name="LouBio" />
=== Central States Baha'i School in the 1930s ===
==== 1931 ====
The July 1931 edition of ''Bahá'í News'' published the announcement of the program at the Central States Bahá'í Summer School, the first name of the school, August 1–9 with lodgings and two meals a day for $10-$12 for the week and noted correspondence should be sent to Helen Whitney Eggleston to an address in Detroit.<ref name="BN53">{{cite magazine |title=Central States Summer School |magazine=Bahá'í News |issn=0195-9212 |page=5 |issue=53 |date=July 1931 |url=http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=01&page=425 | access-date =Jan 25, 2018}}</ref> The faculty included Harlan and Grace Ober, already active in the religion many years in the [[Bahá'í Faith in Greater Boston|Boston area]] and [[Green Acre Bahá'í School]], Mabel and Howard Ives, [[Dorothy Beecher Baker|Dorothy Baker]], Fanny Knobloch, and Maye Harvey Gift.<ref name="WO13">{{cite magazine |title=Security that endures; glimpses of the Kitab-i-Iqan |author=Maye Harvey Gift |magazine=World Order |pages=278–84, 288 |date=Dec 1947 |volume=13 |issue=9 |url=https://bahai.works/index.php?title=File:World_Order_Vol13_Issue9.pdf&page=28 | access-date =Jan 25, 2018}}</ref><ref name="centenary" /> Mary Collison<ref name="BN596">{{cite magazine |title=Rebuilding Louhelen; US National Spiritual Assembly approves $1.8-million restoration of historic Michigan Bahá'í School |magazine=Bahá'í News |issn=0195-9212 |pages=10–11 |date=Nov 1980 |issue=596 |url=https://bahai.works/index.php?title=File:Baha%27i_News_596.pdf&page=11 | access-date =Jan 25, 2018}}</ref> and Miss McKay were support staff.<ref name="BN53" /><ref name="BN56">{{cite magazine |title=Central states summer school 1931 |author=Bertha Kirkpatrick |magazine=Bahá'í News |page=4 |date=Nov 1931 |issue=56 |editor1=Sarah Walrath |editor2=Albert Windust |url=http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=01&page=448 | access-date =Jan 25, 2018}}</ref> The Obers and Ives planned the school as a committee.<ref name="centenary" /><ref name="BN56" /> 35 Baha'is and friends from six states attended all the sessions and about 50 others, mainly from Detroit and Flint, came as day students to one or more classes.<ref name="LouhelenHistory" /><ref>{{cite news |title=Baha'i conducting school near Flint |newspaper=Detroit Free Press |location=Detroit, MI |page=4 |date=8 Aug 1931 |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/14565933/new_bahai_school_being_held_later/| access-date =Jan 25, 2018}}</ref> Baker's entire family attended.<ref name=Coppertogold>{{cite book |author=Dorothy Freeman |title=From copper to gold: the life of Dorothy Baker |date=January 1984 |publisher=G. Ronald |isbn=978-0-85398-177-0 |url=https://bahai-library.com/pdf/g/gilstrap_copper_gold_baker.pdf |pages=134–7, 177–85}}</ref> The sessions were held that year in a wooded area sloping down to a clear stream, either in a lodge on the hillside or in an open-air amphitheater nearby. Some 20 people attended the first day and about 90 total attended at least one day of activities.<ref name="NineDays">{{cite magazine |title=Nine days at Louhelen Ranch |author=Bertha Hyde Kirkpatrick |magazine=Star of the West |pages=280–3 |date=Dec 1931 |volume=22 |issue=9 |url=http://starofthewest.info/viewer.erb?vol=22&page=281| access-date =Jan 25, 2018}}</ref><ref name="centenary">{{cite book |title=The Bahá'i centenary, 1844–1944: a record of America's response to Bahá'o'lláh's call to the realization of the oneness of mankind, to commemorate the one hundredth anniversary of the birth of the Bahá'i faith |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=s1fYAAAAMAAJ |year=1944 |publisher=Bahá'í publishing committee |pages=219–220}}</ref>
The Egglestons devoted themselves to developing the school's facilities. A small barn was partitioned into private rooms and became a [[Pullman (architecture)|Pullman type]] lodge, providing long narrow rooms. A dining porch was added to the main house to improve the serving of meals.<ref name="LouhelenHistory" /> 80 acres of the Eggleston farm were allotted to be used by the school.<ref name="centenary" /> A ravine was named Ridvan Garden.<ref name="BN56" /> Details were covered in the two main periodicals of the religion of the day - ''Bahá'í News'',<ref name="BN56" /> and ''[[Star of the West (Bahá'í magazine)|Star of the West]]'', the oldest large scale journal of the religion in the US, in December, 1931.<ref name="NineDays" /> Topics of the sessions included economics, the problem of greed and it's amelioration and another was practical and inspirational approaches to being trustworthy. There was also a daily class in public speaking, study of [[`Abdu'l-Bahá]]'s talks, a leading figure of the religion, children's classes, and international subjects. Recreational activities in the afternoon included swimming and horse-back riding. The author of the ''Star of the West'' article recalled there being a log cabin overlooking the ravine. Bertha Hyde Kirkpatrick, a Baha'i since at least 1927,<ref>{{cite magazine |title=Publications |magazine=Bahá'í News |issn=0195-9212 |page=3 |date=Nov 1927 |issue=20 |url=http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=01&page=158 | access-date =Jan 25, 2018}}</ref> was present at this first session<ref name="BN56" /><ref name="NineDays" /> and would long serve the school.
Noting the need for a center of activity between the coasts and the progress of the Eggleston and noted some 35 attendees with 90 at least some session. A message from [[Shoghi Effendi]], then head of the religion, was quoted "To achieve success in such manner the first year is certainly beyond what we could expect."<ref name="BWv7">{{cite book |author=Horace Holley |title=Baha'i World |chapter=Current Baha'i activities; Louhelen Summer School |publisher=Baha'i Publishing Committee |series= |volume=vol 7 |date=1939 |pages=63–4 |url=https://bahai.works/Bahá’%C3%AD_World/Volume_7 |chapter-url=https://bahai.works/index.php?title=File%3ABW_Vol7_Pt1.pdf&page=62}}</ref>
==== 1932 ====
In 1932, the summer school became a recognized Bahá'í institution.<ref name="centenary" /> A committee was appointed by the National Spiritual Assembly of the United States consisting of Lou Eggleston, Dorothy Baker, and Bertha Hyde Kirkpatrick.<ref>{{cite magazine |title=Baha'i summer schools; 3. Louhelen Ranch, Davison, Mich. |magazine=Bahá'í News |issn=0195-9212 |page=4 |date=June 1932 |issue=63 |url=http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=01&page=516 | access-date =Jan 25, 2018}}</ref> Subjects and faculty were published ahead of time.<ref name="BN199" /> The cost for participants was published at $9 to $12 for room with 2 meals per day for nine days and suggesting dinners in nearby Davison. In addition to the school July 31 to August 9, events and meetings happened beyond the school session.<ref name="BN70">{{cite magazine |title=Report of Central States Baha'i summer school |author1=L. W. Eggleston |author2=Dorothy Baker |author3=Bertha Kirkpatrick |magazine=Bahá'í News |issn=0195-9212 |pages=3–4 |date=Jan 1933 |issue=70 |url=http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=01&page=553| access-date =Jan 25, 2018}}</ref><ref name="BN74">{{cite magazine |title=Central states summer school |author1=L. W. Eggleston |author2=Bertha Hyde Kirkpatrick |magazine=Bahá'í News |pages=19–20 |date=May 1933 |issue=74 |url=http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=01&page=597 | access-date =Jan 25, 2018}}</ref> A specific inter-community conference took place July 31.<ref>{{cite magazine |title=Committee announcements |magazine=Bahá'í News |issn=0195-9212 |pages=3–4 |date=Sep 1932 |issue=66 |url=http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=01&page=527 | access-date =Jan 25, 2018}}</ref> Faculty and subjects included Bishop Brown ([[Bahá'í administration]],) and Mrs. Brown (outline for the study of ''[[The Dawn-Breakers]]'',) Pearl Easterbrook ([[Prayer in the Bahá'í Faith|prayer]] and meditation,) Albert Vail (study of ''The Dawn-Breakers'',) Dorothy Baker (who oversaw a youth meeting of some 18-20 and had many supplemental presentations by other faculty,)<ref name="BN199">{{cite magazine |title=Milestones at Louhelen |magazine=Bahá'í News |issn=0195-9212 |pages=14–5 |date=Sep 1947 |issue=199 |url=https://bahai.works/index.php?title=File%3ABaha%27i_News_199.pdf&page=14 | access-date =Jan 25, 2018}}</ref> Ruth Moffett (the [[Bahá'í House of Worship (Wilmette, Illinois)|Temple]] being built, and spiritual illumination,) Maye Harvey Gift ([[Bahá'í Faith and the unity of humanity|amity work]] – in 1935 Gift would co-produced the first compilation of Baha'i references to race issues,<ref>{{cite magazine |title=Reviewing and editorial |magazine=Bahá'í News |issn=0195-9212 |pages=11–2 |date=Apr 1935 |issue=91 |url=http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=01&page=755 | access-date =Jan 25, 2018}}</ref> circulated more in 1942<ref>{{cite magazine |title=Baha'i lessons; Race Unity |author1=Maye Harvey Gift |author2=Alice S. Cox |magazine=World Order |pages=363–4 |date=Jan 1942 |volume=7 |issue=10 |url=https://s3.amazonaws.com/worldorder/Volume7/World_Order_Vol7_Issue10.pdf | access-date =Jan 25, 2018}}</ref> which was revised and republished in expanded form in 1943,<ref>* {{cite magazine |title=This crucial year; progress report no 3 issued by the National Spiritual Assembly for the period Jul 1-Aug 31, 1942 |magazine=Bahá'í News |issn=0195-9212 |pages=2–3 |date=Oct 1942 |issue=156 |url=http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=02&page=506 | access-date =Jan 25, 2018}} * {{cite magazine |title=This crucial year; progress report no 8 issued by the National Spiritual Assembly for the period March 1-31, 1943 |magazine=Bahá'í News |pages=1–2 |date=Apr 1943 |issue=162 |url=http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=02&page=546 | access-date =Jan 25, 2018}} * {{cite magazine |title=New Publications |magazine=Bahá'í News |page=3 |date=Nov 1943 |issue=168 |url=http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=02&page=592 | access-date =Jan 25, 2018}} * {{cite news |title=Race and Man by Maye Harvey Gift and Alice Simmons Cox… |newspaper=The Indianapolis News |location=Indianapolis, IN |page=6 |date=25 Nov 1943 |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/15629635/bahai_compilation_by_maye_harvey_gift/ | access-date =Jan 25, 2018}} * {{cite news |title=Race and man… |newspaper=Oakland Tribune |location=Oakland, CA |page=22 |date=5 Dec 1943 |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/15648794/brief_summary_of_bahai_compilation_by/ | access-date =Jan 25, 2018}} * {{cite news |title=In "Race and Man"… |newspaper=The Honolulu Advertiser |location=Honolulu, HI |page=16 |date=21 Dec 1943 |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/9426682/summary_of_book_by_bahai_publishing/ | access-date =Jan 25, 2018}}</ref> and 1956,<ref>* {{cite magazine |title=Baha'i in the news |magazine=Bahá'í News |issn=0195-9212 |pages=12–3 |date=Jul 1956 |issue=306 |url=http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=04&page=367 | access-date =Jan 25, 2018}} * {{cite magazine |title=Special price offered on presentation copies |magazine=Bahá'í News |page=11 |date=Nov 1956 |issue=309 |url=http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=04&page=434| access-date =Jan 25, 2018}}</ref> also owned by Rev. Martin Luther King Jr,)<ref>{{cite book |author1=Martin Luther King |author2=Clayborne Carson |author3=Susan Carson |title=The Papers of Martin Luther King, Jr., Volume VI: Advocate of the Social Gospel, September 1948 March 1963 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Y3ElDQAAQBAJ&pg=PA638 |year=1992 |publisher=University of California Press |isbn=978-0-520-24874-8 |page=638}}</ref> Elizabeth Greenleaf, chair of the new national youth committee<ref name=BN71>{{cite magazine |title=Bahá'í youth activities |magazine=Bahá'í News |pages=5–6 |date=Feb 1933 |issue=71 |url=http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=01&page=559 | access-date =Dec 29, 2017}}</ref> (on youth consultation,)<ref name="BWV">{{cite book |title=Baha'i World |publisher=National Spiritual Assembly of the Baha'is of the US and Canada |volume=5 |date=1936 |pages=104–5 |url=https://bahai.works/Bahá’%C3%AD_World/Volume_5 |chapter=Central State summer school program July 31 - August 7, 1932| chapter-url =https://bahai.works/index.php?title=File:BW_Vol5_Pt1.pdf&page=103}}</ref> as well as some youth. Several of the faculty – Vail, Gift, and Easterbrook being leaders from various Illinois communities – Urbana and Peoria especially – though Vail had already more of a nation visibility and had given up a likely winning career as a unitarian universalist minister and in the case of Easterbook position in the New Thought movement.<ref>{{cite thesis |author=Lori L. Vodden |date=Dec 1992 |title=The development of the Baha'i Faith in Central Illinois, 1898-1957 |type=MS |publisher=Illinois State University Department of History |oclc=27667936 }}</ref> In addition to Baker's family, [[Jakob Kunz]]'s daughters attended.<ref name=Coppertogold/>
A meeting was arranged by local Rev. J. M. Pengelly<ref name="BN70" /> who became interested from the 1931 meeting where he attended the classes by Harlan Ober.<ref name="BN199" /> Pengelly also invited Ruth Moffett to address his church group.<ref name="BN74" />
Average attendance during the school approached 60 (twice the previous year) and filled the accommodations.<ref name="BN199" /> An additional 10-20 from Detroit attended some days. 18-20 youth attended and some paid their way by service. Dorothy Baker supervised the youth who held their own forum, daily elected a chair from their own group and called for two short talks for each session followed by an open forum limiting the speaker to not comment further. Albert Vail's study of ''The Dawn-Breakers'', included instruction on Muslim history. Also $50 was gathered for donation to the Temple construction following a fundraiser by Orcella Rexford. She had attended at the urging of friends at the last minute and later wrote an article for ''Star of the West''.<ref>{{cite magazine |title=The Baha'i summer school at Louhelen Ranch |author=Orcella Rexford |magazine=Star of the West |pages=194–6 |date=Sep 1932 |volume=23 |issue=6 |url=http://starofthewest.info/viewer.erb?vol=23&page=194 | access-date =Jan 25, 2018}}</ref> She recalled driving past the ranch house on the winding driveway with a nine-sided building hosting water resources and staying in one of the new cabins. She noted the Pullman Lodge was two-story and that people had come from as far as California and Maine as well as one who had finished a round-the-world trip. Half the attendees were called youth and looked forward to "doing something". The closing night the youth presented an original play "O wad some Pow'r the giftie gie us to see ourself as others see us" quoting [[Robert Burns]] and imitating various of the elders present.
Again the Egglestons looked at improving, adding, and remodeling buildings between this session and the next.
==== 1933 ====
Amidst the closing of banks and tightening money during the early part of the year via the [[Emergency Banking Act]], plans for the summer 1933 moved the school about a month earlier, June 25-July 3.<ref>{{cite magazine |title=Methods used to coordinate teaching program |magazine=Bahá'í News |issn=0195-9212 |page=8 |date=May 1933 |issue=74 |url=http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=01&page=586 | access-date =Jan 25, 2018}}</ref> The national assembly specifically asked that the overall program for promoting the religion across the country was to be presented at Louhelen and [[Green Acre Bahá'í School]]s that year. Dorothy Baker was to lead youth group, and new Pullman Apartments had been added to the barn to accommodate more people.<ref>{{cite magazine |title=Central States Summer School |magazine=Bahá'í News |issn=0195-9212 |page=5 |date=Apr 1933 |issue=72 |url=http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=01&page=567 | access-date =Jan 25, 2018}}</ref> Faculty include Bishop and Mrs. Brown, Allen McDaniel, Harlan and Grace Ober, Elizabeth Greenleaf and Dorothy Baker, Fanny Knobloch, and Lillian Seilken.<ref>{{cite magazine |title=Central States Summer School |author1=L. W. Eggleston |author2=Dorothy Baker |author3=Bertha Hyde Kirkpatrick |magazine=Bahá'í News |issn=0195-9212 |pages=8–9 |date=Jul 1933 |issue=73 |url=http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=01&page=610 | access-date =Jan 25, 2018}}</ref><ref name=BN622-12>{{cite magazine |title=The early years: a flame begins to glow |author=Margaret H. Hildreth |magazine=Bahá'í News |issn=0195-9212 |page=12 |date=Jan 1983 |issue=622 |url=http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=10&page=801 | access-date =Jan 25, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=The third yearly summer school… |newspaper=Detroit Times Saturday |location=Detroit, MI |page=11 |date=June 24, 1933 |url=https://www.genealogybank.com/nbshare/AC01170608203652011011513827894 | access-date =Jan 25, 2018}}</ref> Three meals a day and room were paid for at between $12.50 to $23 for the whole session, average attendance was about 70 and there were 140 total attendees.<ref>{{cite magazine |title=Report of the Central States Summer School |author=Birth Hyde Kirkpatrick |magazine=Bahá'í News |page=4 |date=Oct 1933 |issue=78 |url=http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=01&page=624 | access-date =Jan 25, 2018}}</ref> Elizabeth Greenleaf opened the session with a presentation on meditation and prayer, then Harlan Ober, assisted by Greenleaf, reviewed [[Bahá'í administration]] as it was understood then - Allen McDaniel was sick. Dorothy Backer gave daily talks from ''The Dawn-Breakers''. Afternoon public meetings attracted a few visitors. Youth did the planning of evening events. Some 26 youth participated in total and included some non-Baha'is. Philip Sprague came late and gave a talk on the progress of the Temple. $500 was raised for it. Ruth Moffett gave a talk. [[Rúhíyyih Khanum|Mary Maxwell]], soon to marry Shoghi Effendi and change her name to Rúhíyyih Khanum, also gave two talks based on ''The Dawn-Breakers''. The final advertised program of faculty and topics was: Elizabeth Greenleaf ([[Kitáb-i-Íqán]],) Greenleaf and Harlan Ober (Baha'i Administration,) Dorothy Baker (''The Dawn-Breakers'',) Ober (religion and society,) Gretch Westervelt (new education,) Orcella Rexford (tomorrow,) Grace Obert (cycle of life,) Fanny Knobloch (Bahá'í Faith to South Africa,) Harlan Ober (New civilization,) and Baker (cosmic consciousness of unity.)<ref name="BWV" />
==== 1934 ====
Planned for June 30 to July 8, the faculty proposed were: Allen B. McDaniel, [[Mary Hanford Ford]], Shahnaz Waite, Gretchen Westervelt, Dorothy Baker, and Philip Sprague.<ref name="BN82">{{cite magazine |title=Committee Announcements; 4. Central States Summer School |magazine=Bahá'í News |issn=0195-9212 |pages=2–3 |date=Apr 1934 |issue=82 |url=http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=01&page=665 | access-date = Jan 25, 2018}}</ref> Topics were to include Baha'i administration, ''The Dawn Breakers'', and the Bible. A youth conference of 16 people in Lima, Ohio, gathered from Ohio, Indiana, Illinois, Michigan, and Wisconsin, at the end of March consulted about Louhelen.<ref>{{cite magazine |title=Central States Summer School announcement |magazine=Bahá'í News |issn=0195-9212 |page=3 |date=May 1934 |issue=83 |url=http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=01&page=670 | access-date = Jan 25, 2018}}</ref> They first noted a change in date for the youth session to June 25-8 and faculty and subjects as: devotionals by Dorothy Baker, Bahá'í ideals in a forum by Harlan Ober, effective leadership by [[Marion Holley]], (Olympian in the 1928 games,) spiritual aspects of the teachings by Mary Hanford Ford, Bible study and comparative religion by James McCormick, and had rates from $5 to $8 for four days, meals, and board. At the time it was the only such session among any of the Baha'i schools.<ref name="centenary" /> However it happened July 10–13 instead of late June, and Dorothy Baker returned to lead the session assisted by Philip Sprague.<ref name="BN82" /> Mary Maxwell and James McCormick also assisted the youth group meeting.<ref name="BWv7" /> The youth group focused on dramatic re-enactments.<ref name=Coppertogold/>
The general session of nine days was to cost between $12.50 to $18.50. Detroit newspapers noted the gathering at Louhelen as well as the organizing committee including Bertha Hyde Kirkpatrick and L. W. Eggleston.<ref>{{cite news |title=Bahai (sic) movement to hold conclave |newspaper=Detroit Free Press |location=Detroit, MI |page=4 |date=9 Jun 1934 |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/15378035/bahai_conference_at_louhelen_school/ | access-date =Jan 25, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Conclave to be held by Bahai movement |newspaper=Detroit Times Saturday |location=Detroit, MI |page=10 |date=June 9, 1934 |url=https://www.genealogybank.com/nbshare/AC01170608203652011011513829052| access-date =Jan 25, 2018}}</ref> They also listed the members of the year's Detroit Assembly including Lou Eggleston as chair and Mrs. Eggleston as corresponding secretary.
Sylvia Paine wrote a summary of her experience at the school in the session for the September ''Star of the West'' edition.<ref>{{cite magazine |title=What is a Baha'i summer school? |author=Sylvia Paine |magazine=Star of the West |pages=181–4 |date=Sep 1934 |volume=25 |issue=6 |url=http://starofthewest.info/viewer.erb?vol=25&page=181 | access-date = Jan 25, 2018}}</ref> She recounted how two youth visitors looking for riding horses chanced upon the Baha'i school in session and stayed a half hr to hear of the ideas. Paine noted the school conference was 14 days long. Meditation and prayer, narratives of Baha'i history, principles of governance, and there was room for swimming and playing tennis, baseball or horse riding. Piano playing was also to be found as well as sing-alongs. She also noted the youth gathering for four days for the first time, and there was a conscious attempt to vary the faculty. She also states the goals of the schools:: to deepen one's knowledge of the religion, to have an opportunity for Baha'is to meet and find friendships, to inform seekers, and be a testing ground for spirit and precepts meet. A letter from Shoghi Effendi was addressed to that school's session.<ref name="BNR119">{{cite magazine |title=Extracts from Letters written on behalf of Shoghi Effendi |magazine=Baha'i National Review |page=6 |date=Apr 1982 |issue=119 |url=https://bahai.works/index.php?title=File:National_Bahai_Review_119.pdf&page=6 | access-date = Jan 25, 2018}}</ref> Presenting the high goals of virtues, he said, ""the work in which you are engaged is dear and near to my heart and constitutes one of the most vital aspects of the manifold activities of our beloved Faith."<ref name="BNR119" />
==== 1935 ====
At the spring national convention Dale Cole described a youth group in Flint, MI, founded by the influence of the Louhelen Summer School, who then formed a Spiritual Assembly in 1935.<ref>{{cite magazine |title=The twenty-seventh annual convention - a summary of the proceedings; Friday evening |magazine=Bahá'í News |issn=0195-9212 |page=2 |date=Jun 1935 |issue=92 |url=http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=01&page=762| access-date = Jan 25, 2018}}</ref> This was also highlighted by the youth committee reported by Marion Holley.<ref name=BW6-Youth>{{cite book |author=Marion Holley |title=Bahá'í World |publisher=Bahá'í Publishing Committee |volume=6 |date=1937 |location=New York, NY |pages=426–35 |url=https://bahai.works/Bahá’%C3%AD_World/Volume_6 |chapter=Youth activities through the Bahá'í World; an estimate and survey of international events 1934-1936 | chapter-url =https://bahai.works/index.php?title=File:BW_Vol6_Pt2.pdf&page=247}}</ref>
The 1935 season was scheduled to begin with a youth session June 24–27 with faculty and subjects as: Dorothy Baker (Baha'i Life), Bishop Brown (Baha'i approach to world problems), Shoghi Effendi's letters (run by the "Young People's Council"), What is the Baha'i movement (under the direction of the "Council"). This was followed by the general session June 29-July 7 with faculty and subjects: [[Horace Holley (Bahá'í)|Horace Holley]], (Baha'i activities,) [[Stanwood Cobb]], (''Security in a failing world'', based on his 1934 book,) Loulie Matthews (''Divine Art of Living'', material of which was gathered and published as early as 1940, see [[Bahá'í Faith on life after death#Bahá'íliterature|Bahá'í Faith on life after death]]), and a second general summer session August 19–24 not announcing faculty yet.<ref>{{cite magazine |title=Baha'i Summer Schools - preliminary announcement 1935 program; 3. Central States (Louhelen Ranch) |magazine=Bahá'í News |issn=0195-9212 |page=4 |date=Mar 1935 |issue=90 |url=http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=01&page=736 | access-date = Jan 25, 2018}}</ref>
An updated program appeared in July outlining the second session with its first faculty Carl Scheffler and E. Lenore Morris.<ref>{{cite magazine |title=August session of Central States Summer School |magazine=Bahá'í News |pages=4–5 |date=Jul 1935 |issue=93 |url=http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=01&page=769 | access-date = Jan 25, 2018}}</ref> The final faculty announced was: Mrs. Barry Orlova, Stanwood Cobb, Dorothy Baker, Bishop Brown, Horace Holley, and Mamie Seto, a Bahá'í from Hawaii,<ref>{{cite news |title=Central Union |newspaper=The Honolulu Advertiser |location=Honolulu, HI |page=10 |date=8 Nov 1931 |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/9121856/bahais_mrs_anthony_mamie_seto_and/ | access-date = Jan 25, 2018}}</ref> with members of the Lansing Bahá'ís attending including George and Mrs. Angell, Cora Reed, Ed and Mrs. Whitney, H. A. and Mrs. Jersey, William and Mrs. Warner, Earl Shetterly, Marie Fox, Bert and Gale Peek, Allen McLean.<ref>{{cite news |title=New world order is taught at camp |newspaper=Lansing State Journal |location=Lansing, MI |page=16 |date=25 Jun 1935 |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/10135839/bahai_summer_school_at_louhelen/| access-date = Jan 25, 2018}}</ref> The Central States Baha'i Summer School Committee sent a letter to ''Bahá'í News'' published in a summer 1935 supplement saying the school will be held June 29 at the request of the national teaching committee and responding to the telegram from Shoghi Effendi and that reservations be sent in as quickly as possible.<ref>{{cite magazine |title=Letter from Central States Summer School |magazine=Bahá'í News (insert) |issn=0195-9212 |page=16 |date=Aug 1935 |url=http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=01&page=792 | access-date = Jan 25, 2018}}</ref>
[[Marion Holley]] organized a survey of Bahá'í youth in America published in 1936 and found that by far the largest mid-western gathering of youth to that date was at the Louhelen in 1935.<ref name="BN99">{{cite magazine |author=Florence C. Mattoon |title=Chicago and mid-western youth activities |magazine=Bahá'í News |pages=5–6 |date=Apr 1936 |issue=99 |url=http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=01&page=829 | access-date =Dec 4, 2017}}</ref> Another youth meeting was planned to be held in 1936 chaired by Wildrid Barton of Winnetka, IL.<ref name="BN99" /> The idea of a survey was mentioned in 1934 by the new nationally organized Bahá'í youth committee,<ref>{{cite magazine |title=Youth committee |magazine=Bahá'í News |pages=23–4 |date=May 1934 |issue=74 |url=http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=01&page=601 | access-date =Dec 29, 2017}}</ref>
==== 1936 ====
The youth session for 1936 was planned June 22-5; faculty were advertised as Bahiyyih Lindstrom, Dorothy Baker, and Stanwood Cobb.<ref name="BN100">{{cite magazine |title=The Baha'i Summer Schools; Louhelen Ranch |magazine=Bahá'í News |issn=0195-9212 |pages=2–3 |date=May 1936 |issue=100 |url=http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=01&page=844| access-date =Jan 25, 2018}}</ref><ref name="BN525">{{cite magazine |title=Out of a handful of dust, part 2 |author=by Philip Christensen |magazine=Bahá'í News |pages=15–21 (see page 19) |date=Dec 1974 |issue=525 |url=http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=08&page=836 | access-date =Jan 25, 2018}}</ref><ref name="Opening Saturday…">{{cite news |title=Opening Saturday… |newspaper=Detroit Free Press |location=Detroit, MI |page=4 |date=27 Jun 1936 |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/14566266/louhelen_bahai_school/ | access-date =Jan 25, 2018}}</ref> Some 80 youth attended and listed Glen Shook among the faculty.<ref name="BN107">{{cite magazine |title=Louhelen Summer School |author1=L. W. Eggleston |author2=Bertha Kirkpatrick |author3=Dorothy Baker |author4=E. J. Meissler |author5=Garreta Busey |author6=Bishop Brown |magazine=Bahá'í News |issn=0195-9212 |page=8 |date=Apr 1937 |issue=107 |url=http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=01&page=919 | access-date =Jan 25, 2018}}</ref> The Chicago Bahá'í youth oversaw the sports, afternoon and evening entertainments and they developed their own basic rules of conduct centered on the honor system.<ref name="BN107" /> Discussions included the attitude towards the growing WWII (then brewing mostly in Europe,) and relationships with ecclesiastical organizations were among the topics. Garreta Busey gave a class on public speaking. The general session followed with faculty Dorothy Baker, Glenn Shook, and Stanwood Cobb.<ref name="BN107" /> Baker's attendance was in the context of having given up her savings for [[Bahá'í pilgrimage]] as a contribution for the Bahá'í Temple and her talks included her choice in a marriage partner being guided more by prayers than by her attraction to a willing suitor.<ref name=Coppertogold/>
The densest and largest concentration of Bahá'í youth in America was in the Midwest from the south of the Urbana-Peoria region north through Chicago to Milwaukee-Kenosha, and across America by far the largest gathering of youth to 1936 was at Louhelen.<ref name=BN99/><ref name=BW6-Youth/>
This was followed by the general session June 28-July 5 including faculty Allen McDaniel, Glenn Shook, and Stanwood Cobb.<ref name="BN100" /><ref name="BN525" /><ref name="Opening Saturday…"/> A second session was added for August 2–9 with faculty Mamie Seto, Marzeih Carpenter (later Gail), and Willard McKay; two of the classes were on Islam/Islamic culture. The cost advertised for the 4 day youth session was $5, and general sessions per day of $1.35 to $2.10. L. W. Eggleston was still advertised leading the school in the ''Detroit Free Press''.<ref>{{cite news |title=Central States Bahai (sic) summer… |newspaper=Detroit Free Press |location=Detroit, MI |page=11 |date=20 Jun 1936 |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/15378063/louhelen_bahai_school_lead_by_l_w/ | access-date =Jan 25, 2018}}</ref> A brief profile and speakers at the school was profiled in the ''Lansing State Journal''.<ref>{{cite news |title=Baha'i will hear Washington woman |newspaper=Lansing State Journal |location=Lansing, MI |page=9 |date=28 Jul 1936 |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/9964288/bahai_talk_at_home_of_george_and_mrs/| access-date =Jan 25, 2018}}</ref> Recognizing the historical character of the development, the relatively new Bahá'í national archives established under the National Spiritual Assembly called for materials for the summer schools to be preserved.<ref>{{cite magazine |title=Classification of materials for preservation in national and local Baha'i archives |magazine=Bahá'í News |pages=7–8 |date=Oct 1936 |issue=103 |url=http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=01&page=878 | access-date =Jan 25, 2018}}</ref> The summer 1936 school at Louhelen was noted as one of the places an "inter-community" conference was held with a member of every assembly and group in the state present.<ref>{{cite magazine |title=Inter-community teaching conferences |magazine=Bahá'í News |issn=0195-9212 |page=4 |date=Dec 1936 |issue=104 |url=http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=01&page=885 | access-date =Jan 25, 2018}}</ref>
The second general session had faculty Maime Seto, Marzieh Carpenter, and Willar McKay.<ref name="BN107" /> Note was taken of newspaper articles by Clarissa Bean of Flint,<ref name="BWv7" /> and in Detroit, if briefly.<ref>{{cite news |title=Baha'i school to open |newspaper=Detroit Times |location=Detroit, MI |page=2 |date=August 1, 1936 |url=https://www.genealogybank.com/nbshare/AC01170608203652011011513862262 | access-date =Jan 25, 2018}}</ref> A public tour of Louhelen by Roscoe Springston, chair of the Detroit assembly, was advertised as well as some sessions available such as by Marzieh Carpenter and other classes offered.<ref>{{cite news |title=Baha'is plan tour Aug. 9 |newspaper=Detroit Times |location=Detroit, MI |page=6 |date=August 1, 1936 |url=https://www.genealogybank.com/nbshare/AC01170608203652011011513862488| access-date =Jan 25, 2018}}</ref>
==== 1937 ====
Bertha Hyde Kirkpatrick presented at the Bahá'í national convention about the schools in April.<ref>{{cite news |title=Baha'i assembly to attract many |newspaper=Lansing State Journal |location=Lansing, MI |page=11 |date=28 Apr 1937 |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/10136112/bahai_national_convention_talks/ | access-date = Jan 25, 2018}}</ref>
The program committee oversaw all sessions for 1937 with the youth committee delegated for their session.<ref name="BN106">{{cite magazine |title=Louhelen Summer School |magazine=Bahá'í News |issn=0195-9212 |pages=7–8 |date=Mar 1937 |issue=106 |url=http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=01&page=906 | access-date = Jan 25, 2018}}</ref> Members of the program committee were L. W. Eggleston chair, and members Bishop Brown, E. J. Miessler, Doroth Baker, Garreta Busey, and Bertha Hyde Kirkpatrick served as secretary for the group. The youth committee had members Marguerite Reimer, (soon to be married to [[William Sears (Bahá'í)|William Sears]]), Florence Mattoon, Wilfrid Barton, (and a youth of Lima, Ohio, to be elected by youth present.)
The youth session was advertised running June 27-July 1; faculty advertised were Willard McKay, Annamarie and Margert Kunz, Garretta Busey, Marzeih Carpenter, and 1928 Olympian [[Marion Holley]].<ref name="BN106" /><ref>{{cite news |title=Racine Baha'is will attend Michigan meet |newspaper=Racine Journal-Times |location=Racine, WI |page=19 |date=24 Jun 1937 |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/15333194/attending_louhelen_bahai_school_youth/ | access-date = Jan 25, 2018}}</ref> Some attended from Buffalo, NY.<ref>{{cite news |title=Bahai (sic) summer schools |newspaper=Buffalo Courier-Express |location=Buffalo, NY |page=8 |date=Jul 10, 1937 |url=http://fultonhistory.com/highlighter/highlight-for-xml?altUrl=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FNewspapers%252021%2FBuffalo%2520NY%2520Courier%2520Express%2FBuffalo%2520NY%2520Courier%2520Express%25201937%2FBuffalo%2520NY%2520Courier%2520Express%25201937%2520-%25205615.pdf| access-date = Jan 25, 2018}}</ref> A youth then non-Bahá'í in California later wrote of her experience coming to the religion after being much impressed by a faculty of the Louhelen 1937 session as an article in 1942's ''World Order magazine''.<ref>{{cite magazine |title=The spirit of power confimeth thee |author=Helen Griffing |magazine=World Order magazine |pages=96–103 |date=June 1942 |volume=8 |issue=3 |url=https://bahai.works/index.php?title=File%3AWorld_Order_Vol8_Issue3.pdf&page=26 | access-date = Jan 25, 2018}}</ref>
The first general session then ran July 3–11 with faculty Allen McDaniel, Marzieh Carpenter, Garetta Busey, and Marion Holly.<ref name="BN106" /><ref>{{cite news |title=Baha'i summer school opens at Louhelen ranch |newspaper=Detroit Free Press |location=Detroit, MI |page=5 |date=3 Jul 1937 |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/15378118/bahai_allen_mcdaniel_at_louhelen/ | access-date = Jan 25, 2018}}</ref> A class on publicity was done at Louhelen in July 1937 by Mrs. Wendell E. Bacon and draft articles accomplished in the class were sent to area newspapers and Lou Eggleston himself published a long article on the history of the Louhelen school in the Davison newspaper.<ref>{{cite magazine |title=Publicity committee |author1=Virginia Camelon |author2=Nina Matthisen |author3=Edna Eastman |author4=Mary Haggard |author5=Edna True |magazine=Bahá'í News |issn=0195-9212 |pages=6–8 |date=Dec 1938 |issue=121 |url=http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=02&page=116 | access-date = Jan 25, 2018}}</ref>
The second general session ran July 31-August 8 with faculty N. M. Firoozi, Glen Shook, and Dorothy Baker. Room and board for general sessions per day per person ran $1.50 to $2.15.<ref name="BN106" /> Lothar Shurgast, former spy for Germany, also came as faculty in August.<ref>{{cite news |title=Ex-spy will speak at Baha'i gathering |newspaper=Detroit Free Press |location=Detroit, MI |page=4 |date=7 Aug 1937 |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/14566358/bahai_lothar_shurgast_former_spy_with/ | access-date = Jan 25, 2018}}</ref> Some Binghamton, NY, Bahá'ís were noted attending Louhelen this August session.<ref>{{cite news |title=Baha'i members attend 2 national conferences |newspaper=Press and Sun-Bulletin |location=Binghamton, NY |page=11 |date=2 Aug 1937 |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/15355859/attending_conventions_at_bahai_schools/ | access-date = Jan 25, 2018}}</ref>
==== 1938 ====
In April 1938 the national library committee reported in ''Bahá'í News'' that it had contributed books to the Bahá'í school libraries including Louhelen.<ref>{{cite magazine |title=Library |author1=Martha Woodsum |author2=Grace Provost Bastedo |magazine=Bahá'í News |page=13 |date=Apr 1938 |issue=115 |url=http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=02&page=41| access-date =Jan 25, 2018}}</ref> Meetings on race unity were held in lead up to the general session.<ref>{{cite news |title=Stresses unity |newspaper=The Times Herald |location=Port Huron, MI |page=5 |date=16 Jun 1938 |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/15548381/bahai_roscoe_springston_talks_at_home/ | access-date =Jan 25, 2018}}</ref> Emogene Hoagg gave study classes in the Flint community staying at Louhelen since May, and was among many faculty that year who spoke in neighboring towns - Carl Scheffler, Robert Faines, McDaniel, Harlan Ober and Caswell all gave extra talks in the area.<ref>{{cite magazine |title=Louhelen Summer School, 1938 |magazine=Bahá'í News |issn=0195-9212 |page=7 |date=Nov 1938 |issue=120 |url=http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=02&page=103 | access-date =Jan 25, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite magazine |title=Emogene Hoagg, an exemplary pioneer |author=Amine De Mille |magazine=Bahá'í News |issn=0195-9212 |issue=511 |pages=6–11 (see page 11) |date=Oct 1973 |url=http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=08&page=490 | access-date =Jan 25, 2018}}</ref> The first general session August 6–13 had faculty Curtis Kelsey, Helen Bishop, Alice Bacon, Marzieh Carpenter, with costs between $1.50 and $2.15 per day.<ref>{{cite magazine |title=Louhelen Summer School |magazine=Bahá'í News |pages=5–6 |date=Jul 1938 |issue=127 |url=http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=02&page=171 | access-date =Jan 25, 2018}}</ref>
The youth session ran at $1.20 per day for August 16–20 with faculty Virginia Camelon, Edward Miessler, Helen Bishop, Carl Scheffler and Marzieh Carpenter. An article noted some from Lansing attending: Frank and Mrs. Evans, Grace Coltrin, Alverta Hamilton, George H and Mrs. Angell, Charity Ballard, Cora Reed, David and Mrs. Earl.<ref>{{cite news |title=Local Baha'i group to attend 'school' |newspaper=Lansing State Journal |location=Lansing, MI |page=3 |date=19 Aug 1938 |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/9897069/lansing_state_journal/ | access-date =Jan 25, 2018}}</ref> Mrs. Earl was Joy Hill Earl, an African American,<ref>{{cite book |author1=Gwendolyn Etter-Lewis |author2=Richard Thomas |author3=Richard Walter Thomas |title=Lights of the Spirit: Historical Portraits of Black Bahá'ís in North America, 1898-2004 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=L2KVX4mx1xEC&pg=PA111 |year=2006 |publisher=Baha'i Publishing Trust |isbn=978-1-931847-26-1 |page=111}}</ref> while David M. Earl was white.<ref>{{cite news |title=David M. earl to retire from History faculty |newspaper=Focus EMY |location=Eastern Michigan University |pages=1–2 |date=Feb 21, 1977 |volume=22 |issue=27 |url=http://commons.emich.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1067&context=focus | access-date =Jan 25, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |title=In Memoriam 1992-1997 |editor=Paul Vreeland |chapter=David. M. Earl (1911-1996)|chapter-url=https://bahai-library.com/pdf/bw/memoriam_bw_1992-1997b.pdf |publisher=Baha'i World Centre |date=2010 |pages=345–6 |url=https://bahai-library.com/bahai_world_memoriam_1992-1997 |isbn=978-0-87743-357-6}}</ref> Thus the campus hosted an inter-racial black-white couple in 1938. A talk from faculty and attendees also followed a school session.<ref>{{cite news |title=Harlan Ober to speak |newspaper=The Times Herald |location=Port Huron, MI |page=10 |date=29 Aug 1938 |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/15548461/bahai_harlan_ober_talk_at_louhelen_and/ | access-date =Jan 25, 2018}}</ref>
A change in 1938 was an added youth session and changed one of the general sessions into a laboratory session as suggested by Marion Holley.<ref name="BN199" /> The laboratory session was added to allow students to concentrate on special projects; in 1938 it was a study project of 10 days by H. Imogene Hoagg, and a project to reach out to neighboring communities with literature and conversations, coordinately by Margarite Reimer.<ref name="BN199" />
Cobb's lectures developed for Louhelen classes in recent years were presented as a series of articles in ''World Order magazine'' across 1938 and collected and printed as a book as well.<ref>* {{cite magazine |title=Summer school lectures in book form |magazine=Bahá'í News |page=6 |date=Nov 1938 |issue=120 |url=http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=02&page=102 | access-date =Jan 25, 2018}} : See : *{{cite magazine |title=Religious foundations for character |author=Stanwood Cobb |magazine=World Order magazine |pages=191–7 |date=Aug 1938 |volume=4 |issue=5 |url=https://bahai.works/index.php?title=File:World_Order_Vol4_Issue5.pdf&page=33| access-date =Jan 25, 2018}} * {{cite magazine |title=Self-development |author=Stanwood Cobb |magazine=World Order magazine |volume=4 |issue=6 |pages=227–34 |date=Sep 1938 |url=https://bahai.works/index.php?title=File:World_Order_Vol4_Issue6.pdf&page=27 | access-date =Jan 25, 2018}} * {{cite magazine |title=The law of duty |author=Stanwood Cobb |magazine=World Order magazine |volume=4 |issue=7 |pages=258–63 |date=Oct 1938 |url=https://bahai.works/index.php?title=File:World_Order_Vol4_Issue7.pdf&page=18 | access-date =Jan 25, 2018}}</ref>
==== 1939 ====
Having books donated the previous year there was need for a library building, and it was erected and called the Refuge in 1939,<ref name="Impact" /> through financial support of Amelia Collins and Dorothy Graf.<ref name="centenary" /> It was raised with labor donated by Lou and George Eggleston.<ref name="BN199" />
The first session in the summer of 1939 was a general session August 6–13 with faculty Curtis Kelsey, Helen Bishop, Alice Bacon, and Marzieh Carpenter; the second youth session ran from August 16–20 with faculty Virginia Camelon, Edward Miessler, Helen Bishop, Carl Scheffler, and Marzeih Carpenter, at $1.20 per day.<ref>{{cite magazine |title=Louhelen Summer School |magazine=Bahá'í News |page=5 |date=Jul 1939 |issue=127 |url=http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=02&page=171 | access-date = Jan 25, 2018}}</ref> The endeavor of the school was encouraged and commented on via a letter written on behalf of Shoghi Effendi to the Louhelen School on July 29.<ref>{{cite book |title=Lights of Guidance: A Baháí Reference File |url=https://bahai.works/Lights_of_Guidance |editor=Helen Hornby |chapter=XLVII; Bahá'í summer schools and institutes | chapter-url =https://bahai.works/Lights_of_Guidance/Summer_Schools#1907._Bah.C3.A1.E2.80.99.C3.AD_Youth_Attendant_at_Louhelen_Shoulder_Responsibility_in_Connection_with_Development_of_the_Bah.C3.A1.E2.80.99.C3.AD_University |edition=2nd |orig-year=1983 |year=1988 |publisher=Baháí Pub. Trust}}</ref>
A later session in August had faculty Helen Bishop and Marzieh Carpenter.<ref>{{cite news |title=Mrs. Bishop will join staff of Baha'i school |newspaper=Detroit Free Press |location=Detroit, MI |page=8 |date=5 Aug 1939 |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/14566393/staff_at_louhelen_bahai_school_helen/ | access-date = Jan 25, 2018}}</ref> Mrs Kenneth Christian spoke at the school in 1939.<ref>{{cite news |title=Woman Baha'i leaders will open series in city |newspaper=Detroit Free Press |location=Detroit, MI |page=18 |date=2 Nov 1940 |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/4930022/bahai_mrs_kenneth_christian_talks_at/ | access-date = Jan 25, 2018}}</ref>
Some attendees of the school sessions came from Lansing,<ref>{{cite news |title=To open Baba'i (sic) summer school |newspaper=Lansing State Journal |location=Lansing, MI |page=2 |date=25 Jun 1939 |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/10136290/bahai_summer_school_at_louhelen_edna/ | access-date = Jan 25, 2018}}</ref> Detroit,<ref>{{cite news |title=George R. Trues hosts in home |newspaper=Detroit Free Press |location=Detroit, MI |page=12 |date=26 Jul 1939 |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/15378236/george_r_and_mrs_true_host_alice/ | access-date = Jan 25, 2018}}</ref> and newly weds Alice Halvorsen and Arthur Hendershot came all the way from Miami, Florida.<ref>{{cite news |title=Miss Halvorsen will be married |newspaper=The Miami News |location=Miami, Florida) |page=7 |date=29 Jun 1939 |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/13312476/bahai_wedding_of_alice_halvorsen_and/ | access-date = Jan 25, 2018}}</ref> Overall there were 54 youth in the first session and 47 in the second session.<ref name="WOv6i3">{{cite magazine |title=Baha'i Schools |author=Genevieve L. Coy |magazine=World Order magazine |volume=6 |issue=3 |pages=89–97 |date=Jun 1940 |url=https://bahai.works/index.php?title=File:World_Order_Vol6_Issue3.pdf&page=15 | access-date = Jan 25, 2018}}</ref> The youth classes for 1939 were reviewed in the October 1940 issue of ''Baha'i Youth'' by Betty Scheffler.<ref name="BN132" />
The first winter session at Louhelen held in the new library<ref name="centenary" /> came in 1939-1940 for December 26 to January 1 with subjects [[pioneering (Bahá'í)|pioneering]], where a volunteers to leave their home for the purpose of supporting the religion somewhere else, deeper study, presenting the religion without public speaking, and psychology of attracting individuals and groups to the religion; registration was limited to 10 people and the cost was $2.25 per day.<ref name="WOv6i3" /><ref>{{cite magazine |title=Winter sessions at Louhelen School |magazine=Bahá'í News |issn=0195-9212 |page=8 |date=Nov 1939 |issue=131 |url=http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=02&page=210 | access-date = Jan 25, 2018}}</ref> The faculty were Francis Stewart, Bertha Hyde Kirkpatrick, Ether Neal Furbush, and Harry Jay.<ref name="BN132">{{cite magazine |title=Louhelen School |magazine=Bahá'í News |issn=0195-9212 |page=12 |date=Jan 1940 |issue=132 |url=http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=02&page=224| access-date = Jan 25, 2018}}</ref> Mrs. George Angell of Lansing was one of the attendees,<ref>{{cite news |title=Mrs. George Angel… |newspaper=Lansing State Journal |location=Lansing, MI |page=24 |date=28 Dec 1939 |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/10136367/bahai_mrs_george_angelsic_goes_to/ | access-date = Jan 25, 2018}}</ref> as was Mrs. George R. True of Detroit.<ref>{{cite news |title=Mrs. George R. True… |newspaper=Detroit Free Press |location=Detroit, MI |page=12 |date=22 Feb 1940 |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/15378273/mrs_george_r_true_guest_of_l_w_and/ | access-date = Jan 25, 2018}}</ref>
==== 1940 ====

==== 1941 ====

Kirkpatrick went to a … |newspaper=The Olivet Optic |location=Olivet, MI |page=5 |date=Feb 27, 1941 |url=http://fultonhistory.com/Newspaper%2024/Olivet%20MI%20Optic/Olivet%20MI%20Optic%201939%20Aug-May%201942/Olivet%20MI%20Optic%201939%20Aug-May%201942%20-%200738.pdf | access-date = Jan 25, 2018}}</ref> The Library was noted to have reached 1800 books, more than doubled, a year later; the collection had been reviewed by a public librarian in Detroit, and the collection had been redone according to the Dewey-Decimal system.<ref>{{cite magazine |title=Our Baha'i schools |magazine=Bahá'í News |issn=0195-9212 |issue=142 |pages=11–12 |date=Mar 1941 |url=https://bahai.works/index.php?title=File%3ABaha%27i_News_142.pdf&page=12| access-date =Jan 25, 2018}}</ref> That spring the Egglestons toured New York state in visiting several cities.<ref>{{cite magazine |title=Progress in teaching; Upper New York |magazine=Bahá'í News |issn=0195-9212 |pages=6–9 |date=Mar 1941 |issue=142 |url=https://bahai.works/index.php?title=File:Baha%27i_News_142.pdf&page=8 | access-date =Jan 25, 2018}}</ref>
The printed program for the first youth session June 29-July 5, 1941 had faculty former Assistant Attorney General in Ohio (1937–38) and African-American [[Helen Elsie Austin|Elsie Austin]] and Virginia Camelon, while Mrs. Rexford C. Parmalee, Lottie Graeffe and the Milwaukee Youth Group organized the evening program and the cost was $1.35 per person per day.<ref name="BN143">{{cite magazine |title=Baha'i school programs; Louhelen Ranch, Davison MI |magazine=Bahá'í News (insert) |issn=0195-9212 |pages=1–2 (layout is backwards) |date=May 1941 |issue=143 |url=http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=02&page=369 | access-date =Jan 25, 2018}}</ref> The Laboratory session followed for July 8–17 with faculty Harry Jay, Solon Fieldman, Lotte Graeffe, members of national Baha'i committees, with costs of $1.60 to $2.25 per person per day.<ref name="BN143" /> A separate vacation session followed July 19 - August 8 with informal meetings and a chance to practice Spanish and learn Latin American culture for rates of $1.50 to $2.25 per person per day. A general session ran August 10–17 with faculty Albert Windust, Alice Simmons Cox, (summa cum laude<ref>{{cite news |title=High honors at college |newspaper=The Daily Times |location=Davenport, IA |page=15 |date=9 Jun 1925 |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/15797034/later_bahai_alice_simmons_cox/ | access-date =Jan 25, 2018}}</ref> and founding [[Phi Kappa Phi]] member at [[Lombard College]] in 1925,<ref>{{cite journal |publisher=Phi Kappa Phi |author=Katherine Reed |title=What the chapters are doing |journal=Phi Kappa Phi Journal |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=cQfuAAAAMAAJ&lpg=RA3-PA62&ots=3gQAdyCiGr&dq=%22Alice%20Simmons%20Cox%22%20-maye&pg=RA7-PA35 |date=Dec 1926 |volume=6 |issue=2 |pages=61–2}}</ref> and posthumous honor award winner from [[Knox College (Illinois)|Knox College]],)<ref>{{cite web |website=Knox College Alumni |publisher=Knox College |title=2017 Scroll of Honor recipients |date=2017 |url=https://www.knox.edu/alumni/alumni-awards/scroll-of-honor?ss=printShullaw | access-date =Jan 25, 2018}}</ref> Bertha Hyde Kirkpatrick, and various forum and informal talks was advertised. Lastly, a second youth session ran August 20–26 with faculty Robert Gaines, F. St. George Spendlove, Margaret Ruhe, and cost $1.35 per person per day.<ref name="BN143" />
Bertha Kirkpatrick attended a planning session for the school in May.<ref>{{cite news |title=Mrs. Bertha Kirkpatrick… |newspaper=Battle Creek Enquirer |location=Battle Creek, MI |page=29 |date=27 May 1941 |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/15378360/bahai_bertha_kirkpatrick_attends/ | access-date =Jan 25, 2018}}</ref>

==== 1946 ====
Amidst the spreading new of the [[Atomic bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki]] and the [[Surrender of Japan]], the schedule for the summer of 1946 was: workshop courses June 29-July 10, Junior Youth July 13–19, Mid-summer session July 22–28, Laboratory July 31-August 11, and senior youth August 14–25.<ref>{{cite magazine |title=Louhelen Baha'i school |magazine=Bahá'í News |page=6 |date=Feb 1946 |issue=180 |url=http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=02&page=794 | access-date =Jan 25, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=5 summer sessions scheduled by Baha'is |newspaper=Detroit News |location=Detroit, MI |page=8 |date=June 22, 1946 |url=https://www.genealogybank.com/nbshare/AC01170608203652011011513863851 | access-date =Jan 25, 2018}}</ref> A specific offering was a conference for parents for July 20-1,<ref>{{cite magazine |title=Radio |magazine=Bahá'í News |pages=7–8 |date=June 1946 |issue=184 |url=http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=02&page=832| access-date =Jan 25, 2018}}</ref> …<ref>{{cite news |title=Baha'i youth workers meet |newspaper=Detroit Free Press |location=Detroit, MI |page=8 |date=20 Jul 1946 |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/8826047/bahai_school_louhelen_sessions/ | access-date =Jan 25, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Olivet |newspaper=Battle Creek Enquirer |location=Battle Creek, MI |page=8 |date=22 Jul 1946 |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/15333603/bahai_mrs_david_farrand_assists_at/ | access-date =Jan 25, 2018}}</ref> including a specific children development program.<ref>{{cite news |title=Baha'i school |newspaper=Detroit Free Press |location=Detroit, MI |page=7 |date=13 Jul 1946 |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/14567392/bahai_school_at_louhelen/ | access-date =Jan 25, 2018}}</ref>
The first summer session had Mamie Seto leading a class on Bahá'í ideas on spiritual growth, Paul E. Haney on the Bahá'í administrative order, Arthur Patterson on visual displays and exhibits, and Florence Reed on public speaking.<ref name="BN184">{{cite magazine |title=Louhelen Baha'i School |magazine=Bahá'í News |issn=0195-9212 |page=10 |date=June 1946 |issue=184 |url=http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=02&page=834 | access-date =Jan 25, 2018}}</ref> The Jr youth session had Peggy True on Baha'i beliefs and conduct, Harry Ford on character, Paul Pettit on mapping travels and cultural encounter, Eleanor Hutchens on nature studies in art and natural materials, with time set aside for round-table discussions with Peggy True and Paul Pettit acting as campus counselors. Roberta Christian was director of the parent's conference.
The Laboratory session had Curtis Kelsey on use of Baha'i literature for the public, Emerie and Rosemary Sala on world unity and a book ''The Earth one country'', and Harlan Ober on developing community. Alice Bacon ran evening programs such as on character. The senior youth session had Arnold Ketels on problems of youth connections, Heshmat Ala'i on the cycles of civilizations, Archie Tichneor on the emerging new world order, and Esther Wilson directed a choir, (the choir was recorded on a [[Wire recording|Peirce wire recorder]].)<ref>{{cite magazine |title=Wilmette Letter: 1947 (convention coverage); Magic, 1947 model |author=Marzieh Gail |magazine=Bahá'í News |issn=0195-9212 |page=8 |date=June 1947 |issue=196 |url=http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=02&page=992| access-date =Jan 25, 2018}}</ref> The forum and talks of pioneering were overseen by Leena Boyd and Arnold Ketels. Rates varies from $1.75 to $3.
The mid-summer session was planned with Bahiyyih and Harry Ford directing a session on children and society problems as a combination workshop and lecture including non-Baha'i experts.<ref name="BN184" /><ref>{{cite news |title=Baha'i members at picnic Sunday |newspaper=Waterloo Observer |location=Waterloo, NY |page=7 |date=Jul 12, 1946 |url=http://fultonhistory.com/highlighter/highlight-for-xml?altUrl=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FNewspaper%252024%2FWaterloo%2520NY%2520Observer%2FWaterloo%2520NY%2520Observer%25201946-1948%2FWaterloo%2520NY%2520Observer%25201946-1948%2520-%25200134.pdf | access-date =Jan 25, 2018}}</ref> Leaders in schools of teachers, principles, directors, as well as university faculty<ref>{{cite news |title=Education of child theme of workshop |newspaper=Detroit News |location=Detroit, MI |page=7 |date=July 20, 1946 |url=https://www.genealogybank.com/nbshare/AC01170608203652011011513860011 | access-date =Jan 25, 2018}}</ref> - Dr. E. N. Palmer of Fisk,<ref>* {{cite magazine |title=College and school news; Theme of the seventeenth … |magazine=The Crisis |pages=166–7 |date=June 1946 |volume=53.6 |issue=426 |editor1=Roy Wilkins |editor2=James W. == National establishment ==

The May 1947 ''Bahá'í News'' sought a registrar, normally Helen Eggleston's work since 1931, to handle room assignments, fee collection, and could attend some classes, room and board for services rendered.<ref>{{cite magazine |title=Wanted for Louhelen |magazine=Bahá'í News |page=4 |date=May 1947 |issue=195 |url=http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=02&page=976 | access-date =Jan 25, 2018}}</ref> W. Foster spoke for the Baha'i national convention about the Louhelen school.<ref>{{cite magazine |title=Wilmette Letter: 1947 (convention coverage); Radio (and) Baha'i Schools |author=Marzieh Gail |magazine=Bahá'í News |issn=0195-9212 |page=7 |date=June 1947 |issue=196 |url=http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=02&page=991 | access-date =Jan 25, 2018}}</ref> He noted the sessions, and presented that the school was developing new talent and had begun working on a broad new curriculum. In parentheses Marzieh Gail noted the Egglestons had given the school and surrounding land of 9.5 acres to the national community. In September 1947 it was further publicly announced nine and a half acres were transferred to the trusteeship of the national assembly.<ref name="BN199" /> A deed for the Davison School was set through the Eggleston Trustees for the Benefit of the National Spiritual Assembly of the US and Canada, excluding their residence, was set during 1947, with preliminary steps were being taken to purchase the residence to preserve the organic unity of the establishment.<ref>{{cite magazine |title=May–October, 1947; a summary by the National Spiritual Assembly,; 15 |magazine=Bahá'í News |issn=0195-9212 |page=2 |date=Jan 1948 |issue=203 |url=http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=02&page=1086 | access-date =Jan 25, 2018}}</ref> The 1948-9 national budget showed $1800<ref>{{cite magazine |title=National budget for third year of second seven year plan; 1948-9 |magazine=Bahá'í News (insert) |issn=0195-9212 |page=14 |date=Jun 1948 |url=http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=02&page=1160 | access-date =Jan 25, 2018}}</ref> - this amount was for the primary residence of the Egglestons associated with the school, and the school in general and its land was a gift.<ref>{{cite magazine |title=Treasurer's letter |author=Philip Sprague |magazine=Bahá'í News |page=5 |date=Oct 1948 |issue=212 |url=http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=03&page=17 | access-date =Jan 25, 2018}}</ref> It was also claried the total land acquired was "about 11 acres." The residence and about 2 acres (about 11-9.5) were ultimately purchased for $20K on a valuation of $54K in 1948.<ref name="BN222">{{cite magazine |title=Annual reports; Eggleston trustees |magazine=Bahá'í News |page=11 |date=Aug 1949 |issue=222 |url=http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=03&page=149 | access-date =Jan 25, 2018}}</ref>
A still longer program took place in the summer of 1947.<ref>{{cite magazine |title=Louhelen Baha'i School Summer Program 1947 |magazine=Bahá'í News |page=10 |date=Jun 1947 |url=http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=02&page=994| access-date =Jan 25, 2018}}</ref> Junior youth were defined as 10-14 yrs and their program ran June 30 to July 11. Faculty included Peggy True, Paul Becker and Annamarie Matoon. A workshop session July 14–25 followed with faculty Florence Reed, George R. True, Elizabeth Cheney and Lawrence Hautz. A two day converence for parents had directors Sylvia Paine Parmelee and Rexford C. Parmelee. The mid-summer session continued the Parmelee focus on children and parenting July 28-Aug 1. The Laboratory session followed Aug 4-15 led by faculty Archie Tichenor, Gretchen Westervelt, Mathew Bullock and Bertha Hyde Kirkpatrick A senior youth session, defined for 15 to 20 yrs, was held Aug 18 to 29 and had faculty of [[William Sears (Bahá'í)|William Sears]], Elizabeth Cheney, Arthur Patterson, Helen Patternson, Edith McLaren and Albert Segen. Rates per day per person varied from $1.75 to $3 and individual meals for day visitors was broken out at $0.40 to $0.85.
Attending from Port Huron were Eugene Bradbury, James Loft, Lewis Patterson, Arthur Loft, Shirley Edmunds, Maxine Ann Ketels, Jacqueline Lenk,<ref>{{cite news |title=Return from Baha'i school |newspaper=The Times Herald |location=Port Huron, MI |page=7 |date=15 Jul 1947 |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/15333638/attend_louhelen_bahai_school/ | access-date =Jan 25, 2018}}</ref> and Stanley T. The winter session for 1947-8 Helen Eggleston served as registrar again - dates were Dec 26-Jan 1, for either $3 or $3.50/day with faculty Curtis Kelsey and Donald Corbin.<ref>{{cite magazine |title=Correction; Louhelen Winter Session Dates |magazine=Bahá'í News |page=8 |date=Nov 1947 |issue=201 |url=http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=02&page=1068| access-date =Jan 25, 2018}}</ref> The winter session rates were $2-$3 per person per day and was going to include a special Youth Day even and present two classes.<ref>{{cite magazine |title=Winter session at Louhelen |magazine=Bahá'í News |page=7 |date=Oct 1947 |issue=200 |url=http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=02&page=1055| access-date =Jan 25, 2018}}</ref> Returned….<ref>{{cite news |title=Returns from trip |newspaper=The Minneapolis Star |location=Minneapolis, MN |page=28 |date=7 Jan 1948 |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/15546185/bahai_helen_frink_was_at_louhelen/ | access-date =Jan 25, 2018}}</ref>
Some year before 1947 one of the buildings collapsed during what was called a tornado,<ref name="BN199" /> (there was a [[1946 Windsor–Tecumseh tornado|tornado in Detroit in 1946]].) A picture of the original house and area in 1930 and another from 1947 shows the changes.<ref name="BN199" />
=== 1948-50s ===

The first "homecoming" was planned for Sep 4-5 of Louhelen alumni.<ref>{{cite magazine |title=Homecoming at Louhelen |magazine=Bahá'í News |issn=0195-9212 |page=9 |date=Aug 1948 |issue=210 |url=http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=02&page=1181 | access-date =Jan 25, 2018}}</ref> Very likely more than 150 people attended at least for some hrs.<ref>{{cite magazine |title=Homecoming at Louhelen |magazine=Bahá'í News |page=11 |date=Oct 1948 |issue=212 |url=http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=03&page=22| access-date =Jan 25, 2018}}</ref> The attendees asked the school committee to make it a regular part of the summer program. It was now considered a tradition to begin each day of the session with prayer and meditation. The first program was a concert and then three periods of discussion followed. One was led by Donald Corbin on the history and growth of the administration including a play written by Ruhiyyih Khanum. The next was by Ellsworth Blackwell, his second appearance on campus, on "the challenging requirement". And the last was by Mrs. George A. True, chair of the program committee, with a panel including Edwin Earldley who was chair of the Louhelen maintenance committee reviewing a deep history of the school and operational procedures. A costume party was held the next day with a picnic supper at "the Glen". Alumni sent letters from Switzerland, Brazil, and Japan and audio wire recording were presented - a talk on [[The Seven Valleys]], another to accompany a slide presentation, and from the convention talk about Louhelen. Five alumni Latin American pioneers were also present. ==== 1949-1950 ====
A tentative summary of the 1949 program was published in December 1948 with a teachers training session, two junior youth sessions, a senior youth session, young adult and adult sessions.<ref>{{cite magazine |title=Louhelen looks ahead |magazine=Bahá'í News |page=6 |date=Dec 1948 |issue=214 |url=http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=03&page=43| access-date = Feb 3, 2018}}</ref> The plans advanced for the summer 1949 plan as of January.<ref>{{cite magazine |title=Louhelen plans summer 1949 |magazine=Bahá'í News |page=3 |date=Jan 1949 |issue=215 |url=http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=03&page=53| access-date =Jan 25, 2018}}</ref> However a period of austerity was imposed for 1949 and 1950 by Shoghi Effendi wherein the summer sessions would not take place at any of the three main Bahá'í schools in order to provide the means to finish the [[Bahá'í House of Worship (Wilmette, Illinois)]] for its opening and the priority of the pioneering work in Latin America.<ref name="BN230">{{cite magazine |title=Annual reports, 1949-1950; Treasurer, National Spiritual Assembly; Trusteeships; Eggleston Trustee Maintenance Committee |magazine=Bahá'í News |issn=0195-9212 |page=14 |date=Apr 1950 |issue=230 |url=http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=03&page=252 | access-date =Jan 25, 2018}}</ref> Major maintenance was undertaken at the time adding the septic system.<ref name="BN222" /> A maintenance committee report for 1949-50, composed of Stanley Bagley, chair, Beatrice Earley, secretary, Edwin Eardley, Clinton Wideman, Oscar Ketels and J. Murdoch Eaton, reported that like all Baha'i schools the summer sessions have been closed for 2 years; an inventory process was ongoing and a tenant has been set up in the Eggleston house leased at $75/mth, and the upper floor of the library rented for $400 for four months.<ref name="BN230" /> In the fall of 1950 Paul Pettit was mentioned on school committee of Louhelen.<ref>{{cite magazine |title=Group to commemorate Day of the Covenant |magazine=Lansing State Journal |location=Lansing, MI |page=7 |date=25 Nov 1950 |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/15361574/bahais_holding_day_of_the_covenant_at/ | access-date =Jan 25, 2018}}</ref>
==== 1951 ====
After having met the goal of the Temple construction funding, Shoghi Effendi and the national assembly re-opened the three schools for the summer of 1951.<ref>{{cite magazine |title="Wings to man's life" Baha'i schools reopen in 1951, by the National Spiritual Assembly |magazine=Bahá'í News |issn=0195-9212 |page=3 |date=Feb 1951 |issue=249 |url=http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=03&page=385 | access-date =Jan 25, 2018}}</ref> A tentative program was announced in March,<ref name="BN242-4">{{cite magazine |title=Summer school plans; Louhelen |magazine=Bahá'í News |issn=0195-9212 |page=4 |date=Mar 1951 |issue=241 |url=http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=03&page=398 | access-date =Jan 25, 2018}}</ref> and finalized in April,<ref>{{cite magazine |title=Louhelen |magazine=Bahá'í News |pages=7–8 |date=Apr 1951 |issue=242 |url=http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=03&page=417 | access-date =Jan 25, 2018}}</ref> as follows: Junior youth session 1 ran July 1–6 had faculty Edna Ketels, Laura and Robert Markovich, and Eulie Horne. Junior youth session 2, July 8–13, had faculty Eunice and John Schurcliff, Wima Ridley and Ella Eaton. General session 1 July 15–20 with faculty Harry Jay, Florence Reeb, and Elizabeth Cheney. General session 2, July 22-7, had faculty Margery McCormick, Archive Tichenor, and Elizabeth Cheney. General session 3, July 22-August 3, had faculty Horace Holley and Alice Bacon. General session 4, August 5–10, had faculty Terah Cowart-Smith, Ellsworth Blackwell, and Harlan Ober. General session 5, August 12–17, had faculty Marzieh Gail, John Robarts, and Curtis Kesley. Senior youth session, August 19–24, had faculty Richard Nolan, Marguerite True, and Marzieh Gail. The young adult session had faculty Borah Kavelin, Elsie Austin and Audrey Windheiser. Each session would begin with a social gathering and end with public meetings. Rates for room and board per day varied from $2.25 to $4. There would be a homecoming session September 2–3 scheduled to be run by Paul Pettit, Michael Jamir, and the Lansing Baha'i community.<ref name="BN242-4" /> The maintenance and program committees for Louhelen met at the Bagley home in Flint in March. A significant decision was to offer child care for children 4 yrs old or older for parents attending sessions at a discount from the regular rates - probably half the regular cost.<ref name="BN242-8">{{cite magazine |title=New facilities at Louhelen |magazine=Bahá'í News |page=8 |date=Apr 1951 |issue=242 |url=http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=03&page=418| access-date =Jan 25, 2018}}</ref> As all the sessions were centered on published texts, individuals were encouraged to bring their own copies but could buy then at the school - to facilitate the aim of "a profound study of the Faith, and not mere wide, but superficial, surveys."<ref name="BN242-8" /> The maintenance committee was hoping to provide hot water showers for the first time, and was looking for volunteers to help clean up before the sessions. ==== 1954 ====

The declared priority of the 1954 season was for the [[Ten Year Crusade]] with a line of action on children on the religion, arts and crafts, and recreation, so that parents could attend sessions, and a daily introduction to the religion was set for any speakers; all from July 5 to Sep 3.<ref>{{cite magazine |title=Louhelen Baha'i school |magazine=Bahá'í News |page=6 |date=May 1954 |issue=279 |url=http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=03&page=1046 | access-date =Jan 25, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Bahai school slated for Summer |newspaper=The Times Herald |location=Port Huron, MI |page=7 |date=19 Jun 1954 |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/15371881/louhelen_summer_school/ | access-date =Jan 25, 2018}}</ref> Ona Koppe shared events when she returned to Obio,.<ref>{{cite news |title=Group marks word 'Feast' |newspaper=News-Journal |location=Mansfield, OH |page=6 |date=13 Jul 1954 |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/15391758/bahais_hold_feast_at_home_of_fred/| access-date =Jan 25, 2018}}</ref> while local coverage in Port Huron mentioned Laurence Hautz giving a talk with color slides.<ref>{{cite news |title=Baha'i to hear world traveler |newspaper=The Times Herald |location=Port Huron, MI |page=7 |date=17 Jul 1954 |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/15371936/bahai_laurence_hautz_talk_at_louhelen/ | access-date =Jan 25, 2018}}</ref> Quentin Farrand from Lansing also spoke.<ref>{{cite news |title=In the Army; Youth leads a '3-d' life; work, tests and Faith keep him busy |newspaper=Lansing State Journal |location=Lansing, MI |page=10 |date=28 Jul 1954 |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/15391869/bahai_quentin_farrand_profiled/ | access-date =Jan 25, 2018}}</ref> while a Bahá'í attended Magengo, IL.<ref>{{cite news |title=Mrs. H. L. Becker |newspaper=Marengo Republican-News |location=Marengo, IL |page=20 |date=29 Jul 1954 |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/15334266/bahai_mrs_h_l_becker_going_to/ | access-date =Jan 25, 2018}}</ref> Weekly meetings were established approaching mid-August and Lois Nochman gave a talk.<ref>{{cite news |title=Baha'is to hear school teacher |newspaper=The Times Herald |location=Port Huron, MI |page=3 |date=7 Aug 1954 |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/15391936/weekly_meetings_at_louhelen_lois/ | access-date =Jan 25, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Baha'i meeting Sunday |newspaper=The Times Herald |location=Port Huron, MI |page=7 |date=12 Aug 1954 |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/15334288/bahais_at_louhelen/| access-date =Jan 25, 2018}}</ref> A larger group of Bahá'ís from Hamburg, NY, atteded: James B. and Mrs. McCloskey, sons of Eugene and Mrs. Thorpe -
